Award.AwardTitle: Tracking the origins of an adaptive trait syndrome with ancient DNA
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will trace genetic changes over a 3000 year period to understand the evolution of domestication in sunflower. Understanding how the complex suites of traits associated with domestication are assembled over time is a central but empirically challenging question in evolutionary biology and a topic of critical importance to agriculture, conservation, and human health. Adaptations frequently involve the coordinated change of multiple morphological, physiological, or behavioral characters, and this pattern is especially true with respect to the transformation of wild plants into crops. Domesticated approximately 5000 years ago by Native Americans, this important staple crop has a rich archaeological record and extensive genomic resources. Using cutting-edge DNA sequencing methods, a dataset reflecting the time series covering the domestication period from ancient through contemporary DNA will be developed. The research can provide new perspectives on agriculture and trade by early Native American cultures. Trainees gain international experience at the Centre for GeoGenetics in Copenhagen. A high school genomics curriculum will be developed through a summer internship program at the National Museum of Natural History that directly engages high school students in scientific discovery through initial sequencing of a new plant genome.

Genome-wide studies of ancient DNA have been made possible by recent technological advances and provide a unique opportunity to reconstruct the historical genetic sequence of multi-trait adaptation. By following the timing and order with which beneficial genetic changes, and by inference changes in domestication traits, accumulate, the DNA dataset obtained will address a core debate over how fast domestication proceeded and test key predictions from evolutionary theory. Several hundred candidate domestication genes identified through genomic diversity and gene expression studies will be followed over an archaeological time series covering the domestication period. Using cutting-edge solution-based sequence capture methods to vastly enrich recovery of specific sequences, several hundred of these genes will be genotyped over a time series using sunflower archaeological remains covering the domestication period. By combining this genotypic information with knowledge of gene function, the project will determine which traits evolved earlier during domestication than others and whether those traits share common features. Through integrating the ancient DNA data with existing data on effect sizes, the project will test whether variants associated with large differences in phenotype predominantly appear early or late in the adaptation process. Sunflower is an important crop today, is divergent from its wild relative in many traits, and this genetic study provides a unique opportunity to investigate how and under what conditions different evolutionary forces and genetic phenomena influence the timing and order of beneficial substitutions affecting an integrated set of traits

POR.DRECONTENT:
Adaptations frequently involve the coordinated evolutionary change of multiple aspects of morphology, physiology, or behavior. Understanding how such complex adaptations emerge over time is a central question in evolutionary biology, and examining DNA obtained from archaeological samples provides a unique opportunity to reconstruct the historical genetic sequence of adaptation. By employing recent advances in DNA sequencing technologies that facilitate ancient DNA research, we have traced the genetic changes that occurred as sunflower was domesticated over the past 4000 years. Native American farmers transformed sunflower from a branchy, bushy, wild plant species with many small disks and seeds into a staple crop that produces one large disk with large seeds from an unbranched stem. Sunflower has a rich, well-studied archaeological record that traces this increase in seed and disk size over time, as well as extensive resources for establishing the role of specific genetic changes in this divergence. We assembled a time series of archaeological samples and used a combination of radiocarbon dating, modern and archaeological genome sequencing, and gene expression approaches to understand the genetic history of sunflower domestication. This work has helped test hypotheses about where domesticated sunflower originated, the impact of cultivation on the crop?s genetic diversity, and which genes were early and late targets of selection during this process.

 

Project Outcomes

By dating and measuring the archaeological samples, we demonstrated that sunflower disk and seed size increased through time during the domestication period, although the trend for disk size was more complex than previously considered. Isolation of DNA from the archaeological samples was successful, particularly from kernels, and we often obtained high proportions of sunflower DNA rather than contaminating DNA from bacteria or fungi. Although other samples did have poor DNA preservation, we were able to effectively enrich and sequence genes of interest even from these samples using short RNA baits we designed. Analysis of DNA sequences revealed that substantial portions of the genetic diversity in present in wild sunflower were lost both early in the domestication process and during modern breeding. Our data were also consistent with a single origin of domesticated sunflower in the Eastern and Central United States, and we did not find support for a second center of domestication in Mexico. We also found that the dominant chloroplast genome sequence changes multiple times over the last 4,000 years within the Ozarks, suggesting the primary cultivars grown by the local cultures inhabiting this area may have been repeatedly replaced over time. Analysis of gene sequence and expression differences between modern domesticated and wild sunflower varieties highlighted several hundred genes with variants favored during domestication by Native American farmers, including genes related to seed oil biosynthesis, plant growth hormones, and flowering time regulation. We also investigated the common marshelder, a wild species in the sunflower family related to an extinct North American crop. Our studies found that the genome of marshelder experienced a major size expansion since the last common ancestor with its closest relative, generating variation and novelty that may have been harnessed during its domestication.

 

Broader Impacts

By identifying genes that contributed to sunflower domestication, our work has highlighted potential targets for future breeding efforts. Our work has also generated substantial resources for the sunflower research community and developed the first genomic resources for marshelder. These resources include genome assemblies for a wild sunflower individual and for marshelder as well as substantial genomic data capturing differences in gene expression between wild and domesticated sunflower across many tissues and developmental stages.

 

During the course of the grant, five postdoctoral scholars, seven graduate students, 11 undergraduates, and 14 high school students received training in scientific research. These trainees include 22 female scientists and 14 students who identify with groups underrepresented in science. Undergraduate alumni have gone on to graduate programs in biology or public health (2), post-baccalaureate research positions (2), or to teach high school science (1). Two former postdoctoral fellows are now tenure-track faculty and a third directs a genomics institute and is adjunct faculty.

 

The most ambitious training activity undertaken as part of the project was the Youth Engagement through Science! (YES!) Global Genome Program. Over three years, 14 high school students that had completed one year of the YES! Program at the National Museum of Natural History returned for another summer for a genomics internship. Students began with a two-week genomics methods boot camp prior to six-week mentored projects. YES! Global Genome students often enhanced their opportunities for college acceptances by writing about the program in their applications, and most noted that the program significantly influenced their desire to pursue science in their postsecondary education.
